content.title: Arterial Calcification (Medial vs Intimal)
content.definition: Pathological deposition of calcium in arterial walls occurring in two distinct patterns: intimal calcification (associated with atherosclerosis) and medial calcification (Mönckeberg sclerosis, associated with diabetes and CKD). Critical to distinguish as they have different clinical implications.

key_concepts.description: Calcium deposition within atherosclerotic plaques in the intima; associated with stenosis and flow limitation; irregular, patchy distribution; causes true arterial obstruction
Calcium deposition in the arterial media; ring-like calcification of muscular arteries; does NOT cause stenosis; vessel remains patent but becomes stiff and incompressible
Intimal: eccentric, plaque-associated, causes stenosis. Medial: circumferential (pipe-stem/railroad track), no stenosis, falsely elevated ABI
Medial calcification renders vessels incompressible → falsely elevated or immeasurable ABI (>1.3); misleading for PAD diagnosis; requires toe pressures or alternative testing
Medial calcification: diabetes mellitus, CKD/ESRD, advanced age, hyperparathyroidism. Intimal calcification: traditional atherosclerotic risk factors
Digital arteries less affected by medial calcification; TBI <0.7 suggests PAD in patients with incompressible ankle vessels
Medial: linear, parallel lines along vessel (railroad track or pipe-stem). Intimal: irregular, plaque-associated calcification
Calcified vessels are difficult to clamp, suture, and anastomose; increased risk of dissection; may need endarterectomy or alternative anastomotic techniques
Heavily calcified lesions are harder to cross, dilate, and stent; increased risk of dissection and vessel rupture; may need atherectomy or specialized devices
Calcific uremic arteriolopathy - distinct entity with small vessel medial calcification causing skin necrosis; high mortality; occurs in CKD/ESRD patients

learning_objectives: Distinguish intimal from medial arterial calcification
Understand the impact on ABI measurement
Know when to use toe pressures instead of ABI
clinical_pearls: Mönckeberg = medial = ring-like = stiff but NOT stenosed
Diabetic + CKD = high risk for medial calcification
Railroad track/pipe-stem on X-ray = medial calcification
TBI <0.7 = PAD when ankles are incompressible
Calcified vessels are difficult to operate on - plan accordingly
common_mistakes: Relying on ABI in diabetic/CKD patients (may be falsely normal)
Assuming high ABI means no PAD (could be incompressible vessels)
Not switching to toe pressures when ABI is elevated
Confusing medial calcification (no stenosis) with intimal (stenosis)
